Replace.Text: All Warehouse buildings apply to Mountain tiles, but they cost +1 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold and[icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness Maintenance.
+30% Production from being the Nepal's unique wonder.

Nepal exists at both the edge and the center of the world: nestled in the valleys of some of the highest places on Earth, and at the same time caught between two of the world’s largest nations: geopolitical proximity has allowed it to be a source of trade and resources, while geographical precarity has allowed it to survive. Internally, Nepal is a mixture of largely Buddhist highland peoples, and a largely Hindu lowland majority. In this latter, states arose with varying degrees of interaction with the highlands, creating a balance of power that was as much about coexistence as control: the Hindu Newars and Chhatri of the lowlands formed the core of states, but relied upon the transportation and resource networks of Tamang and Sherpa highlanders.

On the northern frontier of India, and in amongst the high mountain valleys, Nepalese kingdoms existed as tributary states since the fist millennium CE, where the name “Nepala” flickers in an out of the inscriptions of states such as the Guptas. They emerge in force in the 10th century CE, with the founding of Kathmandu, but it is not until the 18th century that a significant power arises – the Gorkha Dynasty, and its founder, Prithvi Narayan Shah.

This was a time of the Muslim-dominated Mughal rule in India, but Mughal troops, reliant upon horse, camel or elephant cavalry, found the steep and cold valleys difficult to control, and highland supply lines to China impossible to encircle. Thus, Nepal became a Hindu holdout as Muslim sultanates and empires warred to their south. When the British entered the scene in India, they, too, found they could not hold the region, though in the Anglo-Nepalese War (1814-1816) they extracted territorial concessions from the more poorly-armed Nepalis and set Nepal up as a protectorate.

This protection led to isolationism under the subsequent Rana dynasty, who allied closely with the British in conflicts ranging from the Indian Rebellion to World War II. Rana-era Nepal was an autocratic and isolationist kingdom that retained its independence owing to its skillful alliances, harsh geography, and strategic geopolitical positioning.

The Rana rose to power on the basis of coups d’etat and assassination, controlling the monarchy via the office of Prime Minister and, at times, enforcing this power via targeted palace murders. Rana loyalty to England, too, was a strategic positioning – its founder, Jung Bahadur, toured British military installations in England and determined that the British were far too powerful to take on. Instead, the Rana gave the British support during the Indian Rebellion of 1857, as well as the elite Gurkha corps that fought with the British in Afghanistan and the two World Wars.

This regime was eventually to fall in the late 1950s, as the Ranas gave way to a period of instability, where constitutional monarchy and monarchical dictatorship vied with each other, just as frustration gave rise to a Communist insurgency. The monarchy then ended after a dramatic massacre in the royal palace in 2001; in 2008, Nepal’s monarchy was officially disbanded.

Boudhanath refers to the district surrounding the Boudha Stupa, the central Buddhist monument of Nepal (an otherwise predominately Hindu country). It is a Buddhist enclave in the city, home to a community of monasteries and worship sites, and its central stupa with its white dome and twin eyes is a symbol of the city and of Nepal in general.

According to legend, the stupa was built by a daughter of Indra, who, cast out of the heavens, sought to build a monument to replenish her own store of merit. From here, the legend has it that Buddhist missionaries set out to teach the dharma northwards and upwards, into the icy peaks and Tibetan plateau where, indeed, most of Nepal’s Buddhists now live.

In 1911, Nepal opened its first hydroelectric power station – only shortly after hydropower had appeared in the United States and India. The country seems suited for it, with dramatic elevation differences and plentiful water streaming down the Himalayan slopes, although since this first project new ones have been slow to appear.
The Nepali name for Chomolungma, Tibetan for “Mother of the World,” is Sagarmatha, “Goddess of the Sky”. The English, and perhaps more familiar, name is Mount Everest.

Nepal exists in the shadow of the great mountains, peaks that scrape moisture from the skies and in so doing shape the ecology and geology of the planet. The winds that blow hot and moist across the Indian subcontinent drop their moisture here, creating dense and fertile valleys on the southern side of the peaks, and the dry highlands of Tibet on the northern side. It is a division that shapes society as well – lowland and highland, rivers and upland desert, Hindu Nepalis and Buddhist Tibetans.

Amar Singh Thapa, dubbed the “Living Tiger” (Jyumdo Bagha) of Nepal, was the commander of the Nepali Army against the forces of the British during the Anglo-Nepalese War. This was a conflict in the early 1800s where the British East India Company sought to control Nepal as a center for wealth and resources. The war raged on, with the better-equipped British nonetheless stymied by the terrain and persistent concerns over malaria. While the British were victorious, their rule in Nepal was limited and under strict control.

Nepal during the modern period is one that rests upon firm control of the state – a paradox, as Nepal’s territory is ethnically and geographically fractured enough to challenge any state. The Singha Durbar – the lion’s palace – was opened in 1908 and signified the iron grip of the Rana Dynasty. These were a series of prime ministers and high officials who effectively controlled the monarchy and ruled with a tight grip both internally and externally. From the Singha Durbar came some of the most significant developments in modern Nepali life – the abolition of slavery, and the recognition of Nepali independence.

Key to the formation of a national consciousness is the media. The Gorkhapatra, the “Nepali mail”, was run largely by the Prime Minister’s office and thus served as a government outlet, heavily censored, for much of its run. Today, it is still running and, though allegations of being too cozy to the government persist, it has managed to outlive its founding regime.

The Sherpa are a Buddhist and Tibetan ethnic minority native to highland areas of Nepal, India and Bhutan. Here, they have historically been able to survive at the highest elevations. They quickly achieved a reputation for being able to brave the land’s highest peaks, and the name became synonymous with intrepid highland explorers, one of the most famous of which is Tenzing Norgay, one of the pair of people to first reach the summit of Mount Everest. Today, Sherpa are deeply involved in Nepal’s tourist industry, especially in guiding hikers around the country’s highest peaks.

The name “Gurkha” in its origin simply refers to the Gorkha Kingdom, one of the progenitors of the modern-day Nepalese state, but in the later 19th and early 20th centuries, the term has come to refer to Nepalese fighters contracted out to fight for other states. Most notably, this was the British – after the Anglo-Nepalese war, the British noted the loyalty and ferocity of Nepali fighters, and formed battalions of Gurkha who were willing to fight for the British. And fight they did – the Gurkhas fought for the British in the Indian Rebellion of 1857, World War I, and World War II. After Indian independence, Gurkhas continued to fight for the British, but many of them entered Indian service.
The most iconic symbol of the Gurkha is their kukri knife – a heavy, forward-curving blade that serves as a machete as well as a weapon.

+2[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production. +1[icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture from adjacent Mountains. Nepal Unique Improvement. Ageless. Does not remove Warehouse bonuses on a tile. Must be placed on Mountain terrain.
Nepal Unique Improvement. Ageless. Does not remove Warehouse bonuses on a tile. Must be placed on Mountain terrain.
Increase your Relationship with all other leaders by 20. Must be built in Tropical adjacent to a Mountain.
Those who teach this ocean of wisdom realize the momentary nature of things.
"Flee to the mountains, once and for all – to the calm, cool rains and the drifting fog."
"Better to die than be a coward."
"Ayo gorkhali! The Gurkhas are upon you!"
"There is an inseparable relationship between the culture of a country and the ideology it follows."
Food and Science Buildings receive an adjacency from Mountains. Claimed Mountains will now receive a Highland Power Station.

Sherpas can activate on an unowned Mountain tile within 5 tiles of one of your Settlements' Palace or City Hall. A path of tiles is claimed back to the Settlement and the Mountain tile is improved immediately with a Highland Power Station.
All Districts adjacent to Mountains receive Defensive Fortifications, one time effect. Follows normal Walls placement rules.

Unlocks the Gift Gurkha Action which Grants a Gurkha to another Civilization. Nepal receives a +10 Relationship with them and 5 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] (Scales by Gamespeed) for the current Relationship Level with them. Can only be done with Friendly of Helpful Civilizations.
Units complete Fortifications in 1 turn if adjacent to a Mountain.
Museums have 2 additional Great Work Slots.
Mountain tiles receive +4 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture in your Capital. Mountains receive +2 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture in other Settlements.
+50% [icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence towards initiating Endeavors if you have the least amount of Settlements, +20% otherwise.
+3 Combat Strength for all units adjacent to Mountain terrain. This is doubled if the unit is also in your territory.

Gives a Gurkha.[n]Accepted: You receive +10 Relationship with them and 5 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture, on Standard Speed, for the current Relationship Level with them. Other Leader receives a Gurkha Unit in their Capital. Can only be done with Friendly or Helpful Civilizations.
{1_leaderName} is offering you a Gurkha unit.
Cancels the Diplomatic Action.[n]{1_initialName}'s[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence is refunded.[n]No new Endeavors between Leaders for {2_cooldown} turns.[n]Relationships worsen.

Nestled high in the Himalayas, and incorporating both highland Buddhist and lowland Hindu populations, Nepal has clung to its sovereignty despite its precarious location. 19th century Nepal was governed by an autocratic group of families, and guarded by the fierce Gurkha warriors. Following an agreement with the British, they maintained a degree of independence at the crown of the world.
Nepal rises above its neighbors, looking to become a world power.
Contains a new Modern Age Civilization, Nepal.
Activate on an unowned Mountain. A path of tiles is claimed back to the Settlement and the Mountain is improved immediately.
Requires an unowned Mountain within 5 tiles of one of your Settlements' Palace or City Hall.

Communities in the high peaks descend into Nepalese valleys, making the difficult trek with goods piled high on their shoulders. While the mountains give Nepal shelter, these former Inca were the true children of the heights.
They need schools, so that they can become Nepali.
Slowly, the Inca language gives way to Nepali, and old customs wither.
The mountain shakes, and snow and ice give way in hissing steam to fire. Struggling, the sherpa seeks to hold some purchase on the mountain, as all falls into flame.
Remain, to see the blood of the earth exposed.
The great double-peaked snowcap rises above the mountain chains, seeming to declare its dominion over the sky.
Arrange an expedition to climb it.
The expedition is a disaster and ends in failure — and death. The mountain guides warn that this is the home of the gods, and none should challenge it.
On the battlefield, Gurkha faces Gurkha. Afterwards, Nepali faces are among the enemy dead.
They are Nepali still. Give them a proper funeral.
They become foreigners upon fighting Nepalis.
Nepal remains independent, a mediating force when others fight. In a world at war, people still shop.
Civilizations rush to claim resources to fuel the fires of progress. Towns are founded, rail lines constructed. But on the Nepalese frontier, a lone sherpa plants a stake in the ground and moves on.
Nepal expands with humility, but expands.
Nepali reputation for evenhandedness and level-headed advice makes Nepali negotiators a necessity within nearly all international disputes.
Surely one might pay a little for this service.

Glacial rivers have long flowed through the valleys of Nepal, but now electricity as well as clear water stream down from the mountaintops. Here is a vision of a mountain utopia — clean, clear, modern surfaces and rugged peaks blending in harmony.
The mountains are a resource; the valleys are home.
+2 Combat Strength when Defending adjacent to Mountains.
To serve in the British Army is an honor respected by both Nepali and foreign sides. The new soldiers march proudly, under foreign eyes, towards distant shores.
Their names are recorded at home, as well.
+15%[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence towards initiating the Gift Gurkha Action.

The Singha Durbar — the lion palace — projects its power across Nepal. But mutterings stir in the capital: the old families feel that their traditional domain is being eclipsed. Government officials report shakedowns and intimidation.
As dawn breaks over the Singha Durbar, the line of Nepalese officials snakes out across the city. Here, a new Nepali order is drafted, one which will stamp the world with a Nepali mark.
Nepal has a part to play in world affairs.
The Good Doctor, High and Low
Following the Sherpa up a steep incline, Dr Rizal looks back at the majesty of Nepal's highlands and lowlands.
The lowlanders are warm and welcoming.
Nepalese Unique Infantry Unit. Stronger, faster, and more expensive.
Tier 1 Nepalese Unique Infantry Unit. Stronger, faster, and more expensive than the Line Infantry.
Tier 2 Nepalese Unique Infantry Unit. Stronger, faster, and more expensive the Rifleman.
Tier 3 Nepalese Unique Infantry Unit. Stronger, faster, and more expensive than the Infantry Company.
Nepalese Unique Scout. Ignores Mountains and Rough Terrain for Sight. Ignores Mountains for Movement.
Activate on an unowned Mountain tile within 5 tiles of one of your Settlements' Palace or City Hall. A path of tiles is claimed back to the Settlement and the Mountain is improved immediately.
Have three Settlements with at least five [B]Mountains[/B].
[B]Mountains[/B] were an important part of [B]Nepal's[/B] identity.

In the maze of canyons and valleys that mark the high country, the roof of {1_Civilization_Adj} lands, the reach of the {1_Civilization_Adj}state falters. Tax collectors and census-takers lose their way, and the people there remain free and proud.
[B]Ashoka[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Nepal[/B].
[B]Lakshmibai[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Nepal[/B].
